Dec. 6

Community Members and Activists Demand Halting Proposed Amazon Facility, Bringing Traffic and Low Paying Jobs into The City

VISUALS: Over 50 community stakeholders will hold a picket line with signs and banners saying, "West Covina Demands Amazon Accountability," "Amazon Stop Exploiting Our Communities," and "We Demand Good Jobs, Clean Air, and Safe Communities." The picket line will be at the proposed location of a new Amazon Logistics Facility in West Covina. Participants will also hold a press conference with a stage truck as activists walk the picket line.

WHEN:  Tuesday, December 7, 2021, at 7:00 am

WHERE:  1211 E Badillo St, West Covina, CA 91790

WHO:  West Covina residents and members of the labor, environmental, and faith communities.

WHAT: On Tuesday, December 7th, West Covina residents and activists will hold a picket line and rally in front of the proposed location of an Amazon Logistics facility. Residents have also recently filed a CEQA lawsuit in an attempt to halt a recently approved Amazon project in the City of West Covina. The lawsuit alleges that the City's granting of the Project Approvals violates CEQA and other applicable zoning/planning laws. CLICK HERE TO VIEW THE LAWSUIT BRIEF.

The proposed Amazon Logistics facility would be a 177,240 square foot distribution center in the heart of West Covina, operating 24 hours a day. The Development Agreement proposed states that the facility is estimated to create 914 daily vehicle trips and does not include proper remedies and more specificity as to the timing and nature of the testing. It is well known that Amazon facilities impact traffic wherever they are located. Recently, community residents in San Diego, California successfully stopped an Amazon development in the region because of a proposed law that would require stronger protections for workers and communities impacted by the project.

Residents say they don't want Amazon's typical high rates of injury, high rates of turnover, and low pay coming into their community. West Covina City Council could do more to support good, family-sustaining middle-class jobs, but Amazon's proposed facility does not accomplish this goal. 

The proposed facility will not create sales tax revenue, and Amazon's developer agreed to provide West Covina only 4 million dollars in so-called "community benefits" over the next 20 years.
